comments.commentBody: LOL, not in your lifetime.
Alabama, really? The poorest State in the Union?
But you are not.

Like 55-tenths from Sarasota, I too wanted ANY day now before ANY MINUTE, although I had significant difficulty coming up with CAMARO.

Other brain-cell issues not involving cows and elephants:

I forgot the well-shod Filipino's first name. For Unitas, I actually thought "Raven" before COLT! Shame on me! And I wavered endlessly about MOSSO. OH NO or aH NO? MUSS or fUSS? So many permutations, I need Numberplay to help me calculate them!

I didn't get SITS UP right away but it was the only thing I entered there.

However, fivethirtyam, you are spot-on and I think you would be a great constructor: That would be a fantastic clue for "speaks" -- probably on a Sunday I think? Or a themeless because it's twisty, but it's awfully cute and I don't think of FRI/SAT XWPs as cute unless they are constructed by Blindauer or accompanied by the only photo I've ever seen of Gorski.

OH MY! Did I say that part out loud?

I voted for Bill, but not with much enthusiasm. I agree with his analysis of where we should go as a city post Bloomberg, but I doubt he will accomplish even 1/2 his goals. Negotiating Union contracts is going to be painful, and I doubt he has Bloomberg's chutzpah to employ policies like no smoking in...., bike lanes, banning trans-fats in restaurants, and other policies which were thoroughly condemned and are now well supported.

I voted for Mark Green in 2001, so what do I know.

Part of the reason for DeBlasio's election and Bloomberg's rebuke is the shabby way the people who are employed by the city were treated. How many are working under expired contracts? How many years have those contracts been expired? Did Bloomberg even bargain with the unions?

Bloomberg made the city a haven for the rich which made the city more expensive for the rest of us. To then refuse to negotiate new contracts is unjust.

As a sometime New Yorker, now somewhat removed (somewhat, as I have family in Brooklyn), my thought is that DiBlasio was a breath of fresh air, with his forthright progressive agenda and vibrant family. What a change to have a real family man in the mayor's office! Not that I hold that against Bloomberg, he was an okay mayor and within the limitations of his class biases a reasonably responsible person. Another major and refreshing factor: DiBlasio embraces racial harmony as just about no other politician could plausibly claim.

Let's not get ahead of ourselves and allow this symbolic victory for progressive values create unrealizable expectations. The rest of New York's power structure and social and infrastructure problems are only going to budge an inch in the next four years, so take a deep breath.

You're right about no coattails. The NJ Supreme Court (with several of his choices on it), overruled his wishes in implementing marriage equality, and in today's election, no mention of the winning ballot initiative to raise the minimum wage, ALSO over his objections? He's got one of the most powerful governorships in the nation, yet has a striking inability to shape governance to his avowed policies. Strange. And the Bible belters will just hate him. Rudy Giuliani, a much more reasonably positioned national Republican candidate, especially after 9/11, went nowhere on the national Republican stage. Look for more of the same with Christie.
its real simple Christie is a democrat.  Every thing he does but for unions is just as democrats do.
shawn - I don't think you know what a Democrat is.

I know the media would like to anoint Christie our next President, but not so fast:

- Christie's vote total tonight is only mildly higher than it was in 2009 (1.24 million to 1.17 million). Christie didn't pull in massive numbers of Democratic votes - those voters just didn't show up for Barbara Buono, who was underfunded, ran a poor campaign, and had the media against her. Buono got 778,000 votes, while in 2009 the Democratic candidate got 1.087 million.

- Christie had almost no coattails, as Democrats will still run the legislature with almost the same margins as before the election

- Christie's abrasive personality will not play well in the heartland or with the national media if they have to deal with him in a Presidential campaign

- Christie has just enough of an independent streak to be anathema to the tea party types who still control GOP primaries

Christie won't get out of the GOP primaries, much less win the general election, if he decides to run in 2016.

www.winningprogressive.org

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Winning-Progressive/195682780442236

You do know that was a movie - and a work of fiction, not a documentary.

It portrayed a small segment of New York - its sordid underbelly - in a dramatic, exaggerated way.

I've lived in NYC nearly all my life - including throughout the 70s - and the vision of NYC portrayed in that movie & in Lhota's failed campaign are as alien to me as science fiction.

That NYC still exists. It has just been hidden behind a curtain of opulence, with the curtain held in place by a militaristic police force. Try living the life of a janitor, construction worker, doorman, delivery person, or taxi driver, and witness life in 2013 NYC from that perspective.

Anyone ever see "Taxi Driver"? Wasn't that NYC in the 70s?
If that is what NYC is returning to, uh-oh...
Mr Rational, you're forgetting your ratios!  It's called "SUPPLY and demand," not "DEMAND."
Wow, well said....

So that's the only place you can go:  regret, crime, businesses will leave, etc.  You have been brainwashed well.  Isn't it interesting that de Blasio won a decisive victory, because he spoke to the incredible wealth disparity in NY.  And how unaffordable it is for everyone except the rich.  Why does that NEVER get addressed by the anti de Blasio crowd.  Your comments are the ramblings of someone deeply afraid of changing the 1% status quo!  De Blasio is a breath of fresh air!!!  YAY NY VOTERS!

Mr. DeBlasio's landslide, by the way only a little over 20% of the registered voters cast a ballot, so I don't take that as a landslide, but the effects of the media telling people he was getting elected no matter what. But a win is a win.

He hasn't spoken to the vast majority of New Yorkers who are neither poor or those who make over $500,000. I think he will tax people though. Mostly us middle class New Yorkers who he hasn't said one thing about. It is all about the rich and the poor with him. The state will not let him tax those making over $500k that's a fact. So where is the money coming from for his policies? Everybody who pays taxes that's where!

I worry about his vision. Is it affordable to me? I don't need his hand in my pocket taking money I need to put aside for my kids college, our retirement and the cost of keeping a house here. We don't get any subsidies from the city, state or federal government like most middle class New Yorkers. We have worked hard for what we have. We are educators in private school, we don't make half of what public school teachers make with our education and years of teaching so we aren't rich.

While I believe we should help the poor in whatever ways we can, it shouldn't have to be at the expense of my children's education or the quality of mine and my wife's life in old age. But Mr. De Blasio has other plans I think. And I am sure it has to do with taking the little money we have left over and more!

80% of those who voted for DeBlasio will come to regret their vote sooner rather than later as crime returns to their neighborhoods, thugs rule the streets and their  employers decamp for cities that welcome them instead of excoriate them for providing jobs and being financially succcessful.  Affordable housing will disappear as formerly low crime neighborhoods where the middle class has found an attractive and affordable place to live are overrun by low level street hustlers and hardened criminals and all the Mom and Pop and other small businesses that cater to the middle class in those neighborhoods shut down for lack of commerce if not for fear of their lives.  DiBlasio says that he wants all New Yorkers to have a shot.  A shot at what and to what endI ask?  If you succeed you will join the so called 1% and become another target of DeBlasio's Socialist rage.  This all happened before during the Lindsey administration, but not many remember the soul deadening spiral of despair that followed.

Your comment, "I suppose it's still equality if everyone is equally poor." clearly demonstrates that NYC is only ok if the REST OF US are poor.

So if this means that classist, elitist, spurning types like yourself who think they are better than the rest of us are leaving to CT, then we DEFINITELY voted in the right man!

I agree.  For those who say he now will be labeled "soft" ... well maybe in that violence laden game.  Others like me call him smart, knowing when its best to take a stand, and say I'm not going to take this anymore.  My guess is his degree and his good sense and upbringing will stand him in good stead.  Good luck to him.

That's because compensation in the NFL is largely based on seniority. You get a contract out of college, and then you have to prove your worth to get that second bigger contract as free agency looms.

Also, you can't go by salary in many cases, because the rookies get huge signing bonuses and smaller salaries. A 2nd round draft choice like Martin would have received a very large bonus.
Incognito, the alleged bullier, t made almost 10x the salary of Martin, his alleged victim, in 2012.
I doubt a board would be an improvement, more latitude to pass the buck.

MPowered: No. Are you someone who measures artistic talent strictly by economics? Because that truly should not even be a measure. Even the art industry in New York has become just that, an INDUSTRY, and a commercial game into itself that remains somewhat independent of talent. But there is talent if you look deep enough. You just have to go outside of the tourist traps in Times Square. And who are you to judge someone's talent, btw?

Betty, these are my feelings exactly. I'm very proud of them and up until this past July I was one but have since moved to Sedona. So, hi neighbor!
I love my new home but New York will always be my city.
Leapy STEM WINDERS are like SIDE WINDERS.  The difference is one bites you in the pocketbook and the other bites you honestly.

One example comes from thousands of displaced families still waiting for help in recovering from Superstorm Sandy one year later.  Christie's promises of support and aid have proven empty and meaningless; but sufficient to get him reelected.
What Joe S has posted is absolutely TRUE!

Hurricane Sandy is quite relevant when assessing Christie's potential support within his own party. I suggest checking out the Club for Growth's website, where they vilify and promise to "primary" Republicans that actually voted for Sandy relief.

It's sick in a way that people should see for themselves.

http://www.primarymycongressman.com/

most tenants in new york have a legal right to share their home with roommate(s,) a romantic/domestic partner, and/or immediate family members. they are not liable to pay a hotel tax for having a roommate and this entire discussion has failed to include this class of former and potential airbnb hosts.

but while shares of 30 days create a legal tenancy relationship which subjects the leaseholder tenant to considerable risk if the roommate stops paying rent.

most renters in new york have at least heard, if not lived through, the horror story of a deadbeat roommate who stopped paying rent and stayed for months while the housing court apparatus took it's sweet time to order the non-payer to move out. non-payment is a financial burden on landlords, too, of course. but the average tenant/leaseholder shares his or her home out of economic necessity, not as an investment, and is even less able to cover months of a roommate's unpaid rent.

airbnb could be the safest, most financially sure source of legal housing shares, if landlords weren't working so hard to make it illegal!

it could also be doing GREAT public relations for the city, drawing an entirely different type of tourist and giving them a more unique, intimate, and real experience of the city than hilton or schrager ever could.

actually, airbnb HAS been doing just that since it's founding.

with any luck, the powers that be will have the good sense to allow it to continue to do so.

Yes-siree, bob, I mean RMC of NYC, Clinton best brace herself for Christie and especially if he somehow is able to manage HIMSELF, i.e., his eating disorder.

A thinner Christie would be unstoppable. He would be able to visually give the message he can overcome great challenge with dedication and discipline, and structure, on a personal level, which America will translate to world politics' savvy.

Our obese, football-loving, sound-bite news addled, reality TV texting America currently judges the worthiness of presidential candidates based on the campaigner's religion and sexual appetite. The American People will no doubt roll over for a thinner Christie - toned and buff even better!

An in-shape Christie will cause much of America, Democrat or Republican to identify with him on a very personal level, considering most Americans who vote are obese (20% over body-fat chart) and those who are not, from gym-rats to smokers will also value the effort Christie makes to be a healthier, better him.

Take heart, NY Times' readers. Odds are he can't do it.
pat b. certainly you cannot disagree with the" loudmouth" moniker often ascribed to HRC. everyone  of her speeches turns into a loud screechy yelling session.
@ DD: I agree completely.
